intro: Camellia sinensis, commonly known as the tea plant, is a flowering evergreen shrub native to Southeast Asia. It produces leaves and buds that are harvested and processed to make various types of tea, including green, black, and white tea. The plant thrives in tropical and subtropical climates with well-drained soil and partial shade. Its leaves contain caffeine and a variety of bioactive compounds that contribute to the flavor and health benefits of tea. Camellia sinensis is cultivated worldwide for its economic and cultural significance in tea production.
